images.copyright: Peggy's Cove Lighthouse, Nova Scotia, Canada (© Pugalenthi/Getty Images)
images.title: Alone but never lonely
images.caption: Peggys Point Lighthouse
images.desc: Perched on a rugged granite outcropping, Peggys Point Lighthouse is a stoic guardian of Nova Scotia's coast. Built in 1914, the 15-metre-tall lighthouse embodies the enduring spirit of maritime Canada. Its beacon was first turned on in 1915. The current lighthouse replaced a wooden structure made in 1868 that was damaged by Hurricane Edna in 1954. The ground floor of the building served as a post office during the summer months until 2009, when Canada Post shut down the service, citing mould growth as a hazard. The lighthouse, now automated, attracts visitors eager to glimpse into Canada's seafaring past and feel the ocean's spray.

og.title: Peggys Point Lighthouse
og.desc: Perched on a rugged granite outcropping, Peggys Point Lighthouse is a stoic guardian of Nova Scotia's coast. Built in 1914, the 15-metre…

images.copyright: Mosaic façade in Registan Square, Samarkand, Uzbekistan (© da-kuk/Getty Images)
images.title: Tile tales
images.caption: Registan Square, Samarkand, Uzbekistan
images.desc: Gather 'round, explorers, as we tiptoe into the Registan Square in the city of Samarkand, Uzbekistan! Meaning 'sandy place' or 'desert' in Persian, Registan was the centre of activity during the Timurid Empire. The square embodied the essence of the Timurid Renaissance, a period of cultural and intellectual revival, which spread throughout the Muslim world between the 14th and early 16th century CE.

images.copyright: Milky Way over Big Bend National Park, Texas (© wisanuboonrawd/Adobe Stock)
images.title: A galactic gig
images.caption: Big Bend National Park, Texas, USA
images.desc: Ready to channel your inner nature enthusiast? Let's explore Big Bend National Park in West Texas, USA. This park is the largest protected area in the Chihuahuan Desert, covering over 3,237 square kilometres. The Big Bend State Park was established on June 12, 1944, when the state of Texas transferred this land to the federal government.

images.copyright: Southern gemsbok in the savanna, Botswana (© Karine Aigner/Tandem Stills + Motion)
images.title: These antelopes are real gems
images.caption: A group of Southern gemsbok in the savannah, Botswana
images.desc: Horns up, heads high! Featured here is a group of gemsboks, a large antelope, reigning over the sprawling savannahs in southwestern Africa. Indigenous to the arid territories of Botswana, Namibia, South Africa and parts of Zimbabwe, they thrive mainly within the Kalahari and Namib Deserts. They can survive in extremely dry conditions and can go without water for weeks, getting moisture from the food they eat. Moreover, gemsboks are adept runners, achieving speeds of up to 60 kilometres per hour. Their distinguishing trait is their notably elongated, straight horns. Although both genders possess these formidable defences, the females' horns tend to be slightly longer and sleeker while the males' horns are thicker with broader bases. So, if you ever find yourself in the sandy plains of the Kalahari, keep an eye out for these desert gems.

og.title: A group of Southern gemsbok in the savannah, Botswana

images.copyright: Osaka at night, Japan (© wichianduangsri/Getty Images)
images.title: City of neon dreams
images.caption: The city of Osaka at night, Japan
images.desc: In the heart of Japan, where the past and future intertwine, lies a city pulsating with life and culture—Osaka. Traditionally an economic hub, Osaka has twice served briefly as the imperial capital, once in the 7th and once in the 8th century. It flourished culturally during the Edo period (1603–1867) and became a major industrial centre after the Meiji Restoration in 1868, which restored imperial rule to Japan.

images.copyright: Bardenas Reales Biosphere Reserve and Natural Park, Bardenas, Navarra, Spain (© Aliaume Chapelle/Tandem Stills + Motion)
images.title: Breath-taking silence
images.caption: Bardenas Reales Biosphere Reserve and Natural Park, Navarra, Spain
images.desc: Within the scenic landscape of Navarra, northern Spain, the Bardenas Reales Biosphere Reserve and Natural Park is like a surrealist painting come to life! This park is renowned for its desert-like landscapes sculpted by millennia of erosion. Featuring rocky plateaus, canyons and whimsically shaped clay structures called cabezos, the park is a playground of geological wonders.

og.title: Bardenas Reales Biosphere Reserve and Natural Park, Navarra, Spain

images.copyright: Skyline of Downtown Montreal, Quebec, Canada (© benedek/E+/Getty Images)
images.title: Lap after lap
images.caption: Canadian Grand Prix 2024
images.desc: Rev up your spirits because the Canadian Grand Prix is shifting into high gear! This Formula One showdown is all set to bring a rush of adrenaline to the Circuit Gilles Villeneuve in Montreal. Named after Canada's homegrown racing hero Gilles Villeneuve, the track has witnessed legendary moments, like Lewis Hamilton's maiden win in 2007, and Jacques Villeneuve racing across his father's namesake circuit. Each lap around the 4.361-kilometre circuit is as unpredictable as it is thrilling, with drivers navigating 70 laps with 14 turns each, including the infamous 'Wall of Champions'—a spot where many racing legends, like Michael Schumacher, have faced hardships.

images.copyright: Family of humpback whales, Dutch Harbor, Alaska (© Jude Newkirk/Amazing Aerial Agency)
images.title: Waves of hope
images.caption: World Oceans Day
images.desc: Today, let's embark on a watery adventure as we celebrate World Oceans Day. This day is about honouring and protecting the world's oceans and serves as a reminder of the critical role oceans play in supporting life on Earth. These gargantuan water bodies, after all, teem with wonders, from the tiniest plankton to the grandest whales like the humpbacks we see here. The oceans also produce almost half of the oxygen on our planet thanks to the photosynthesis of plankton—tiny plants, algae and bacteria. Moreover, they absorb a significant amount of carbon dioxide from the atmosphere, helping mitigate the impacts of climate change caused by human activities.
